Dear Denise R Crawford:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/28/24, a youth was taken to the hospital and was ready for
discharge, but the facility refused to take him back indicating that
they were unaware of the extent of his mental health and
behaviors. Facility did not provide supervision of youth while at the
hospital
Investigation Interviews:
Hospital Social Worker was interviewed via phone on May 30,
2024. Hospital Social Worker reported Youth A was brought to the
hospital via ambulance on May 29, 2024, due to behavioral
concerns. She reported Foster Care Worker was present and was
asked to stay with Youth A while he was in the hospital. Hospital
Social Worker reported Foster Care Worker reported she could not
stay and stated that Hospital Social Worker needed to call
Administrator 2 as Youth A was placed at their facility. She reported
she called Administrator 2 who reported the facility was issuing an
emergency discharge notice of Youth A from their facility as their
program is not equipped to handle Youth A’s behaviors. Hospital
Social Worker reported Youth A was placed at the facility less than
twenty-four hours before arriving at the hospital. She reported
Administrator 2 did not have a clear report from Foster Care Worker
of Youth A’s behavior before accepting the youth into the program.
Hospital Social Worker reported Youth A has been cleared for
discharge from the hospital as of 3pm on May 29, 2024, and there is
no one at the hospital providing supervision or willing to pick up
2

Youth A. She reported did not ask directly for Administrator 2 to send
someone to supervise Youth A as she reported Youth A was
discharged from the program.
Foster Care Director was interviewed via phone on May 30,
2024. Foster Care Director reported he is aware of the situation with
Youth A as Foster Care Worker called him on May 29, 2024, asking
what to do since Hospital Social Worker was asking her to stay. He
reported he gave the direction that it was the residential facility’s
responsibility to provide supervision as they cannot do an emergency
discharge of Youth A. Foster Care Director reported Foster Care
Worker was at the facility on May 29, 2024, to visit Youth A as he just
moved there on May 28, 2024. He reported while Foster Care
Worker was at the facility, Youth A escalated and the facility had an
ambulance transport Youth A to the hospital. Foster Care Worker
went to the hospital as a courtesy as the facility stated they were
understaffed and could not go. Foster Care Director reported there
was a meeting scheduled with Administrator 2 and Therapist for 3pm
on May 29, 2024, to discuss the situation and Administrator 2
canceled the meeting five minutes before it was to begin stating she
had something come up. He reported he has not received anything in
writing from the facility requesting the discharge of Youth A and
stated it took the facility three weeks to review Youth A’s referral
packet before acceptance. Foster Care Director reported all
documentation about Youth A’s behaviors was provided to the facility
for review and with that knowledge of his behaviors still accepted
him. He reported Youth A has unsafe behaviors and requires a two-
person transport with the foster care team. Foster Care Director
reported when Youth A was being transported to the facility on May
28, 2024, Youth A attempted to sexually assault one of the foster
care workers by trying to kiss her. He reported he is frustrated with
the facility as they have not sent any formal request for Youth A to be
moved from their facility and stated the contract does not allow the
facility to do emergent discharges.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via phone on June 3, 2024.
Administrator 2 reported she was present at the facility when police
arrived on May 29, 2024, to help de-escalate Youth A. She reported
when she arrived on the scene Foster Care Worker also arrived
because she had scheduled a home visit with Youth A. She reported
they went inside the home to process more about the situation that
happened before Foster Care Worker arrived and Youth A began to
escalate again. Administrator 2 reported Youth A was causing
damage to vehicles outside, and law enforcement had to restrain
him. Administrator 2 reported Foster Care Worker helped de-escalate
Youth A by providing him candy bars, as the Foster Care Worker
noted Youth A’s grandmother would use this trick to help Youth A’s
behaviors stay calm. She reported Foster Care Worker was going to
3

leave the facility because she needed to get back as she was off of
work at 1pm. Administrator 2 reported she asked Foster Care Worker
not to leave yet as there needs to be a conversation about how to
keep Youth A safe as the facility is not equipped to manage his
behaviors. Foster Care Worker called Foster Care Director about the
situation and the plan was for Youth A to go to the hospital for a
psychiatric assessment and Foster Care Worker would go up to the
hospital. Due to Foster Care Worker’s relationship with Youth A,
knowledge of his case history, and Youth A was only responding to
redirection from her, she was asked to also go to the hospital to
provide more information. Administrator 2 reported she overheard
Foster Care Worker on the phone with Foster Care Director stating
she did not want to get stuck at the hospital and did not feel
comfortable transporting Youth A. It was determined an ambulance
would transport Youth A. Administrator 2 reported about two hours
later she received a phone call from Hospital Social Worker stating
Youth A was ready for discharge. She reported she told the Hospital
Social Worker that an emergency discharge request was being sent
as they were unable to keep Youth A safe with his behaviors.
Administrator 2 reported she was never asked by Hospital Social
Worker to come sit at the hospital with Youth A. She stated that she
did not mention an emergency discharge until she talked to the
Hospital Social Worker because the facility was open to potentially
taking him back to the facility if he received some psychiatric
treatment but since it was behavioral concerns, he met the criteria for
their emergency discharge request. Administrator 2 reported she
would have sent staff to the hospital but because Youth A was at the
facility less than twenty-four hours and Youth A only responding to
Foster Care Worker, she thought that it would be best Foster Care
Worker attend. She reported she never expressed it was because
the facility was understaffed and stated the facility has taken youth to
the hospital in situations before and they make the staffing work.
Administrator 2 reported Therapist sent the emergent discharge letter
on May 30, 2024, to Foster Care Director and prior had multiple
conversations with the foster care department of how the facility
cannot keep Youth A safe at the facility due to his behaviors. She
reported she understands the letter should have been sent earlier but
she wanted to make sure there was support provided to the team
that experienced Youth A’s aggressive behavior as this is not
something the facility ever experiences. She reported the facility did
not receive all information about this youth as it was noted that he did
not have any behavioral issues for two months before being admitted
into the program, but she found out after placement that he had
behavior issues a week before placement that would have met the
criteria for him not to be accepted. Administrator 2 reported the
facility is not able to restrain a youth and they have lower functioning
youth at the facility that would be in danger of Youth A’s behaviors.
She reported she met with the Foster Care Director on Friday, May
4

31, 2024, to talk about this youth and she continued to get pushback
that they are not following the contract and they did not give him a
chance.
Foster Care Worker was via phone on June 7, 2024. Foster Care
Worker reported on May 29, 2024, she was at the facility for a
required home visit with Youth A. She reported Youth A was
dysregulated when she arrived, and it was determined Youth A
needed to go the hospital for evaluation. Foster Care Worker
reported she was asked by Administrator 2 to go to the hospital with
Youth A due to staffing concerns. She reported when she had to
leave the hospital, she told the Hospital Social Worker to call the
facility. Foster Care Worker did not call and talk to the facility when
she left. Foster Care Worker reported Administrator 2 stated when
Youth A was going to the hospital that the facility would be looking
into an emergent discharge pending his evaluation at the hospital
due to his aggressive behaviors. She reported she was not involved
in the meeting on May 31,2024 as she was on vacation.
Therapist was interviewed via phone on June 7, 2024. Therapist
reported she reviewed the referral packed for Youth A when there
was a request for placement at the facility. She reported it was
reported Youth A had not had any AWOL or aggressive behaviors in
the past two months and was stabilized. Therapist reported she was
not aware of his prior placements or sexualized behaviors. Therapist
reported she was involved with the incident that occurred on May 29,
2024, which resulted in Youth A going to the hospital due to sexually
acting out, behavior aggression and property destruction. She
reported she was not involved with the conversation with Foster Care
Worker about who was going to the hospital with Youth A. Therapist
reported she had completed debriefs with Staff 1, Staff 2,
Administrator 1, and Administrator 2 about the events that occurred.
She reported the emergency discharge policy was followed and the
emergent discharge request was sent to Foster Care Director on May
30, 2024. Therapist reported this is the first time they had to utilize
this procedure and because of the heighten situation that occurred
the day prior.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed separately face to face at
the facility on May 30, 2024. Both Staff 1 and Staff 2 were working
when Youth A arrived at the facility on May 28, 2024, around 11am.
They both reported Youth A had no behaviors that day and stated he
was excited to be in a home-like setting. Staff 1 reported the next
morning on May 29, 2024, Youth A was up at 7am with the other
youth. She reported Youth A walked with the boys to the bus stop
and refused to come back into the home. Staff 1 and Staff 2
encouraged Youth A to come in and they called Therapist to come
support. They reported they also informed Administrator 1 and
5

Administrator 2 of behaviors that were going on. Staff 1 reported
Therapist was able to encourage Youth A to come into the home but
was still refusing to follow the daily tasks within the home. She
reported Youth A went into his room and when she checked on him,
he ran into his bed and started to masturbate. Staff 2 reported Youth
A began to throw around things in his room and damage property
within his room. Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported when there was no
reaction being provided by staff to this behavior, he started to go into
the other youth rooms to destroy their property and into the living
room to destroy all the electronics. They reported police were called
but throughout all of these behaviors Staff 1, Staff 2, and Therapist
attempted to verbally de-escalate Youth A. When police arrived, they
brought Youth A out of the home to help calm down and he sat on
the porch. The police left and Foster Care Worker arrived for her
scheduled visit with Youth A. After a few moments went by Youth A
began to kick doors, windows, and staff’s cars. Police were called
back due to behaviors and a plan was made for Youth A to go to the
hospital via ambulance. Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported Foster Care
Worker reported she would sit with Youth A at the hospital since
Youth A's behaviors were towards facility staff. Both Staff 1 and Staff
2 denied being short-staffed at the facility, especially during this time.
It was reported Staff 1, Staff 2, Therapist, Administrator 1, and
Administrator 2 were onsite with only Youth A. Staff 1 and Staff 2
both reported they were unaware of Youth A’s sexualized behaviors
and property destruction concerns. They both reported the facility is
an open facility that works with low-acuity youth as they are not
allowed to restrain youth. Staff 1 and Staff 2 both denied ever being
asked to sit with Youth A at the hospital and have reported in the
past with other youth they have sat at the hospital with youth. They
reported if they do not have enough staff to provide support at the
time a youth needs to go to the hospital then Administrator 1,
Administrator 2, or Therapist will go for support.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 30, 2024. Administrator 1 reported he was called in for support
for the incident that occurred on May 29, 2024, and noted
Administrator 2 was the one to handle the emergency discharge
documentation. He reported he has not been involved with the foster
care agency at this time. Administrator 1 reported he was involved in
reviewing Youth A’s referral packet when the foster care agency was
seeking residential placement. He reported he was unaware of Youth
A having sexualized behaviors and noted if he was aware he would
not have been accepted into the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Incident Report completed by Therapist dated
May 30, 2024- This incident report details the events that
occurred on May 29, 2024, with Youth A. The incident report
6

is consistent with interviews completed with Staff 1, Staff 2,
Administrator 2, and Therapist.
- Facility Emergency and Disaster Procedures Policy with
most recent revision date of June 27, 2023- Policy notes
that if the staff on duty has to accompany a youth to the
hospital, then the on-call staff can be notified to assist with
other youth on the unit.
- Facility Ratio Policy with the most recent revision date of
June 27, 2023- Policy notes that during waking hours the staff
to resident ratio is one staff member to four youth. There is
also one direct care worker or management staff will be
assigned as on-call and if there is no staff designated on-call
then Administrator 1 serves as backup.
- Facility Staffing Schedule for May 29, 2024- Staff 1 and
Staff 2 were on the schedule for day shift with four youth.
Administrator 1 was noted to be the on-call support that day.
- Discharge letter for Youth A dated May 30, 2024- Facility
completed a letter indicating they are implementing an
emergency discharge of Youth A due to Youth A’s aggressive
and assaultive behaviors that occurred on May 29, 2024. The
facility attached the Emergency Discharge Policy. The letter
was sent to Foster Care Director on May 30, 2024. It was
noted the letter was dated May 31, 2024 but sent on May 30,
2024.
- Facility Emergency Discharge Policy with Effective Date
of April 30, 2024- Policy states, “If the behaviors displayed by
the youth become unsafe for youth in question, other youth in
the home, and/or staff (property damage, police interventions,
use of weaponry, aggressive behaviors, sexually explicit
behavior), Pine Way will implement an emergency discharge.
The youth is not safe to return to Pine Way.”
- Email communication with facility and Foster Care
Director date May 30, 2024- Therapist reached out Foster
Care Director via email dated May 30, 2024, at 10:32AM
noting she will be at the virtual meeting about Youth A on May
31, 2024, at 9AM. Foster Care Director responded at May 30,
2024 at 11:35AM noting the contract does not allow for
emergency discharge and offered to pay for addition one to
one staffing support. Therapist responded on May 30, 2024 at
4:50PM providing Foster Care Director with Emergency
Discharge Letter for Youth A from the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of following their discharge
and emergency policy as it pertained to Youth A going to the
hospital. A discharge notice was not sent to the foster care agency
7

until May 30, 2024, which meant the facility was still to provide
care and supervision of Youth A on May 29, 2024, when he was
ready to discharge from the hospital. The facility did not provide
staffing supervision at the hospital while the youth was still under
their care.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered for the facility to make sure their
discharge policy aligns with the contract requirements.
Additionally, clear communication with the hospital, referring
agency and facility need to occur during times of crisis to ensure
proper staffing and planning occur.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
